'''Ernest Joseph "Tabby" Thomas''', (January 5, 1929 – January 1, 2014), also known as '''Rockin' Tabby Thomas''', was an American [[blues]] musician.<ref name="Music">{{cite book
| first= Paul
| last= Du Noyer
| year= 2003
| title= The Illustrated Encyclopedia of Music
| edition= 1st
| publisher= Flame Tree Publishing 
| location= Fulham, London
| isbn= 1-904041-96-5
| page= 181}}</ref> He sang and played the piano and guitar, and specialized in a substyle of blues indigenous to southern Louisiana called [[swamp blues]].<ref name=times-picayune>{{cite web|author=Greater New Orleans |url=http://www.nola.com/music/baton-rouge/index.ssf/2014/01/tabby_thomas_founder_of_tabbys.html |title=Tabby Thomas, founder of Tabby's Blues Box, dies at 84 |publisher=NOLA.com |accessdate=2014-01-02}}</ref>

==Life and career==
Thomas was born and grew up in [[Baton Rouge, Louisiana]]. After graduating he served in the [[U.S. Air Force]], and while serving won a talent contest on [[KSAN (AM)|KSAN]] radio in [[San Francisco]] in 1959.  After making a few unsuccessful recordings for [[Hollywood Records]],<ref name=allmusic/> he returned to Baton Rouge.  He recorded for several small local labels, before he became more successful with [[Excello Records]] in [[Crowley, Louisiana|Crowley]], for whom his records included "Hoodo Party" in 1961.<ref>[http://i1.ytimg.com/vi/ieDdhTu6lOY/hqdefault.jpg  "Hoodo Party" label shot]</ref>  He also worked in various jobs, including a time with [[Ciba Geigy]] where he was a [[trade union|union]] steward.<ref name=times-picayune/>
  
He became one of the best known blues musicians in Baton Rouge with his band the Mellow, Mellow Men, but briefly retired from performing in the late 1960s to set up his own [[record label]], Blue Beat, which released his own recordings and those of other local musicians.<ref name=allmusic>[{{Allmusic|class=artist|id=p30833|pure_url=yes}} All-Music Guide entry for Tabby Thomas]</ref> In 1978, with other members of his family including his son [[Chris Thomas King]],<ref>[http://www.christhomasking.com Website of Chris Thomas King]</ref> he reopened a rundown building on North Boulevard.  He ran the venue as an authentic blues [[nightclub|club]], Tabby's Blues Box and Heritage Hall.  The club moved in 2000 and finally closed in November 2004.  Thomas also became a popular performer in the UK and Europe, where he made regular appearances.<ref name=times-picayune/>   

Thomas had a serious automobile accident in 2002 and a [[stroke]] in 2004, which affected his playing but not his singing.  He later hosted the [[radio station|radio]] show, ''Tabby's Blues Box'', on Baton Rouge stations [[WBRH-FM]] and [[KBRH|KBRH-AM]].  He died in the early hours of January 1, 2014.<ref name=times-picayune/>
